messages.text: Just a quick report: I had a super productive call with Don from MS who originally created the Python extension and is now the primary dev on the Jupyter extension. He outlined the plans that they have for all of this going forward, and it was essentially all I had hoped for. He is going to help us revive my notebook branch, make it work with the current notebook API and the Jupyter extension. For now we're going to drop the custom file format support and will just try to get the Jupyter Notebook support to work properly. The high level architecture is that the Jupyter extension will essentially just do the file read and write, and then we will have a kernel implementation inside our extension that does all the code execution. We will completely bypass the Jupyter ZMQ comm story, and instead rely on the VS Code APIs for kernel execution, so this will all work without a need for an IJulia.jl installation.

elements.text: Just a quick report: I had a super productive call with Don from MS who originally created the Python extension and is now the primary dev on the Jupyter extension. He outlined the plans that they have for all of this going forward, and it was essentially all I had hoped for. He is going to help us revive my notebook branch, make it work with the current notebook API and the Jupyter extension. For now we're going to drop the custom file format support and will just try to get the Jupyter Notebook support to work properly. The high level architecture is that the Jupyter extension will essentially just do the file read and write, and then we will have a kernel implementation inside our extension that does all the code execution. We will completely bypass the Jupyter ZMQ comm story, and instead rely on the VS Code APIs for kernel execution, so this will all work without a need for an IJulia.jl installation.

messages.text: So the tentative plan is that the official Jupyter extension will use ZMQ to execute code if the Julia extension is not installed, but if the Julia extension IS installed, we will "own" the kernel and the execution.

elements.text: So the tentative plan is that the official Jupyter extension will use ZMQ to execute code if the Julia extension is not installed, but if the Julia extension IS installed, we will "own" the kernel and the execution.

messages.text: Thanks for the update.  Yes, I have had really good experiences with the core microsoft developers since reaching out to them.  Jupyter developers less so... I have a bad feeling about jupyter as a software project (the `.ipynb` format isn't going anywhere, but the python jupyer code/kernel/jupyterlab/etc. aren't needed after everyone else implements it and eventually finds better file formats).  I just have a hard time seeing why anyone would use jupyterlab after vscode and github codespaces is up and urnning with all these features.  And the clean typescript setup means that nobody needs to battle conda just to show notebooks.

elements.text: Thanks for the update.  Yes, I have had really good experiences with the core microsoft developers since reaching out to them.  Jupyter developers less so... I have a bad feeling about jupyter as a software project (the
.ipynb

format isn't going anywhere, but the python jupyer code/kernel/jupyterlab/etc. aren't needed after everyone else implements it and eventually finds better file formats).  I just have a hard time seeing why anyone would use jupyterlab after vscode and github codespaces is up and urnning with all these features.  And the clean typescript setup means that nobody needs to battle conda just to show notebooks.

messages.text: I just added automatic plot detection to support detecting VegaLite and Vega plots, which allows thumbnail-generation with no extra white area from Julia plot. <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/pull/1932>

messages.text: My understanding is that `winget` is going to be released in May. I have no idea if the architecture is clean for this sort of thing, but has there been any discussion of a package to install Julia and the vscode extension to make installation idiot proof?

elements.text: My understanding is that
winget

is going to be released in May. I have no idea if the architecture is clean for this sort of thing, but has there been any discussion of a package to install Julia and the vscode extension to make installation idiot proof?

messages.text: Good question... I've also been wondering whether there might be a way to use `winget` to install VS Code extensions, which I think would be the first necessary step. If that works, I'm not sure whether `winget` has the concept of a "meta package", but if they had, then that would presumably be it.

elements.text: Good question... I've also been wondering whether there might be a way to use

winget
has the concept of a "meta package", but if they had, then that would presumably be it.

messages.text:
So I created a project for our v1.2 release here: <https://github.com/orgs/julia-vscode/projects/5>

As of right now I'd say that is the scope of 1.2? If you want to exclude or include something, just comment on the relevant PR/issue.

And then in terms of process, I'd say that once we have everything in that v1.2 project in the "Done" column, we start merging things, ok? So the flow would be that we want _everything_ that is supposed to go into 1.2 ready before we start to merge anything.

elements.text: So I created a project for our v1.2 release here:

As of right now I'd say that is the scope of 1.2? If you want to exclude or include something, just comment on the relevant PR/issue.

And then in terms of process, I'd say that once we have everything in that v1.2 project in the "Done" column, we start merging things, ok? So the flow would be that we want
everything
that is supposed to go into 1.2 ready before we start to merge anything.

messages.text: My hope is that with that we can have `master` as short as possible in a state where we can't ship new versions.

elements.text: My hope is that with that we can have
master
as short as possible in a state where we can't ship new versions.

messages.text: So I'd say the call to the entire team is: lets get all columns other than "Done" empty, either by fixing open issues and approving PRs, or by removing them from this project (and thus scheduling them for a future release).

elements.text: So I'd say the call to the entire team is: lets get all columns other than "Done" empty, either by fixing open issues and approving PRs, or by removing them from this project (and thus scheduling them for a future release).

messages.text: <@U68UUUFPS> <@U6BNE7LTZ> There is one known problem I just discovered with our current design of plot panel by conducting some manual testing: If we generate 2 plots in a row by copying two `@vlplot` commands together into the REPL, since the first plot does not get to load fully (the second plot immediately replaces the first plot in the plot view), the plot panel does not really show thumbnail for plot 1 unless we manually click on the first plot to activate the plot. Do you think it’s a problem that we should fix? If so, what opinions or ideas do you have towards solving this (since I currently have no idea to solve this problem elegantly)?

elements.text: There is one known problem I just discovered with our current design of plot panel by conducting some manual testing: If we generate 2 plots in a row by copying two
@vlplot

commands together into the REPL, since the first plot does not get to load fully (the second plot immediately replaces the first plot in the plot view), the plot panel does not really show thumbnail for plot 1 unless we manually click on the first plot to activate the plot. Do you think it’s a problem that we should fix? If so, what opinions or ideas do you have towards solving this (since I currently have no idea to solve this problem elegantly)?

messages.text: Yeah, I do think we should fix that... Is the problem that there is some timer? I think I don't fully understand the root cause of the problem.

elements.text: Yeah, I do think we should fix that... Is the problem that there is some timer? I think I don't fully understand the root cause of the problem.

messages.text: The root cause of the problem is this, according to my current understanding: if we copy and paste two plot `@vlplot` into the REPL and run them, the plot web view will be set to the HTML of the first plot, and really quickly, the second plot. If the first plot has not finished loading (as plotting Vega requires some time) as well as thumbnail generation and passing, by the time we load the second webview content, it will replace HTML of the first plot, and refresh the webview to the content of second plot, so that the thumbnail of the first plot is not generated.

elements.text: The root cause of the problem is this, according to my current understanding: if we copy and paste two plot
@vlplot

into the REPL and run them, the plot web view will be set to the HTML of the first plot, and really quickly, the second plot. If the first plot has not finished loading (as plotting Vega requires some time) as well as thumbnail generation and passing, by the time we load the second webview content, it will replace HTML of the first plot, and refresh the webview to the content of second plot, so that the thumbnail of the first plot is not generated.
